ARSD, Cyclic redundancy check calculation algorithm
5.1 Cyclic redundancy check calculation algorithm
� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LV_HISTO_CKS_NOT_VLD O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Set to 1 if the cks sum is valid
LV_HISTO_FRZ O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
If set to 1 Information to freeze all Histogramm counter
LV_HISTO_READY O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Set to 1 if all histogramm related data is read out from nvmy, trigger for histogramm fkt
� General Information
This document describes the checksum calculation functionality needed by the data recorder. The actual
project implementation has to be completed and adopted by the project.
5.1.1 Readiness of Histogram data after ECU power up
� General Information
Description:
After power up all Histogram data must be read out from NVMY, this action may take some time depending
on CPU-load and data amount. Histogram function is deactivated as long as this action is not ?nished (LV_
HISTO_READY = 0).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: LV_HISTO_READY =0 at reset
Activation: at ECU power up
� Function Description
IF Histogram data is read out from NVMY
Then LV_HISTO_READY = 1
Endif
5.1.2 Checksum calculation at power up
� General Information
Description:
Compare old OverallCheckSum with New Calculated Checksum of Histogramm data (counter and calibration
data).
� Application Conditions

ARSD, Cyclic redundancy check calculation algorithm
Initialisation: LV_HISTO_CKS_NOT_VLD = 0 at reset
Recurrence: once at ECU power up
� Function Description
New OverallCheckSumRAM) = f(CKS_E2P_MES + PCKS DATASET)
IF NEW CKS = ! saved CKS
Then LV_HISTO_CKS_NOT_VLD = 1 //Reset all Histogram Data/counters
Endif
5.1.3 During normal operation
� General Information
Description:
Check if Histogram calibration data are not changed. If the calibration has changed then all Histogram counters
will be frozen until the next reset.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: LV_HISTO_FRZ = 0 at reset
Activation: every engine operating state
Recurrence: 1s
� Function Description
IF Histogram calibration data changed
Then LV_HISTO_FRZ = 1
Endif
5.1.4 At power down
� General Information
Description:
Histogram Function runs till end of power latch
� Application Conditions
Recurrence: once at power down
� Function Description
After PWL Save Histogram Data and CKS_E2P_MES + PCKS_DATASET

ARSD, Data recorder
Purpose of this module is to perform statistical data measurements of a con?gurable number of system vari-
ables.
These data are :
- detection if measured variable is in a de?ned range YY (class), and counts how many time this condition have
been met (event counters).
- store a history of a con?gurable number of measurements
- a low pass ?lter
These measurements are triggered by 2 de?ned trigger conditions on system variables.
All de?ned data and applicable strategies are selected through calibration.

Storage conditions are computed regarding 3 possible signals :

Physical_Offset = 50% (derived from Output data)
Limits from output data:
8000h ->-50%
FFFFh ->-0,0015%
0000h - >0%

Convertion from signed to unsigned used in SW:
0000h -> -50%
7FFFh ->-0.0015%
8000h -> 0%
FFFFh ->49.1505%
Formula used for C_SC_MIS:
Physical_Value = (Decimal_Value*Resolution) ? Physical_Offset
Decimal_Value = (Physical_Value + Physical_Offset) / Resolution
Formula used for C_SC_MIW:
Physical_Value= Decimal_Value*Resolution
Decimal_Value= Physcal_value/Resolution
Calibration Examples:
For a measurement from -10% to 30%, calibrations will be :
C_SC_MIS = (-10% + 50%)/0.0015 = 26666 =>682Ah
C_SC_MIW =( 40%/ 0.0015) = 26666 =>682Ah
For a measurement from 10% to 40%, calibrations will be :
C_SC_MIS = (10% + 50%)/0.0015 = 40000 =>9C40h
C_SC_MIW = (30%/ 0.0015) = 20000 =>4E20h

5.3.10 Non volatile storage handling of class counters
� General Information
This chapter describes the handling to store and restore the class counters from/to non volatile memory.
The RAM variables for the class counters have a resolution of 4 bytes whereas the resolution of the non volatile
values is con?gurable (1 byte ... 4 bytes).
Depending on the resolution con?guration of the non volatile values the RAM values have to be converted.
This is achieved by appropriate shifting.
If not the full resolution is used for the non volatile storage, the RAM values have to be limited accordingly
before storage.
The ?rst trigger to write to non volatile memory will set LV_HISTO_FRZ_PWL to stop continuous measure-
ment.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation:
Activation: Restore: at startup
Store: at end of power latch
Recurrence: Once each driving cycle
� Function Description
Restore non volatile data:
FOR(1) (i=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_VALUE){
FOR(2) (j=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_CLAS){
FOR(3) (k=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_CLASS_RESOLUTION){
SM_CL[i][j] |= (NVMY_SM_CL[i][j][k] << (k*8bit))
}
}
}
Store non volatile data:
FOR(1) (i=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_VALUE){
FOR(2) (j=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_CLAS){
LimitSM_CL[i][j] according to configured resolution
FOR(3) (k=0 to NC_NR_DREC_MES_CLASS_RESOLUTION){
NVMY_SM_CL[i][j][k] = (SM_CL[i][j] >> (k*8bit))
}
}
}

� General Information
This module provides the generic parts related to OBD Radar functionality.
Remark: only the exported data-?ow are under functional OBD Radar con?guration (NC_USE_OBDS).
Reference documents:
Please ?nd below reference of documents used as bases for this functional speci?cation:
- OBD-Radar speci?cation: ? LH_OBD-Statistikpaket_1_4.doc ?
- OBD -Radar - tester tool interface: "UDS_ODX_Lastenheft_Antriebsstrang_OBD-Radar_akl.doc"
Global overview:
The OBD Radar functionality describes the implementation of an OBD-Statistics package in an engine control
unit, which allows the early detection of component defects or ageing by monitoring various diagnostics in
terms of their distance to a fault memory entry.

ARSD, Customer statistical data
The monitoring of a given diagnostic function is done through the evaluation of a standardized value, which
moves continuously between 0 and 1. A standard value of 0 stands for a like new component whereas a
standard value of 1 stands for a defective component or an error memory record.
The standard values are either formed within the relevant diagnostic features or calculated in a central function
of existing Mode$06 values.
The feature also provides modules to:
- record maximum on standard values for the driving cycle and for the life cycle of the engine.
- store environmental data freeze frame upon condition
- build histogram related to standard values pro?le during life cycle of the engine
All collected and computed data are sent to the customer tester tool via diagnostic service
The architecture of the complete system is shown in the ?gure below.

5.4.3 Central function
� General Information
The Central function uses standard values arrays and Mode$06-arrays; the access to these arrays is con?g-
urable.
From the Mode$06-values standard values are calculated.
All standard values are collected in a common array.
In addition, for all collected provided standard values, status information are provided.
For the collected standard values, maximum values for the current driving cycle and for the life cycle of the
engine shall be calculated.
For each standard value, exists an applicable threshold, and if the threshold is exceeded, one Freeze-frame
with environmental conditions and engine state variables is stored.

#Computation of maximum values for engine life cycle
ACTION_ARSD_ClcObdsMaxValuesELC(IDX_OBDS)

// manage FF only when central function is activated, not required for histogram

#Freeze-frames deletion
ACTION_ARSD_DeleteObdsFrf(IDX_OBDS)
ENDIF (4)
ENDIF (3)
ENDIF (2)
ENDFOR (1)
ENDIF (0)

5.4.7 ACTION_ARSD_ClcObdsMd6StdValues - private function
Description:
The Mode$06-standard values are calculated in a loop over all elements of EWS_posnSrv06_T_VW.
This calculation takes place under the following conditions:
? Current existing identi?er name value is not exceeded current maximum size of Mode$06-values array,
? Valid bit for the updated value is set,
? Valid bit for minimum and/or maximum threshold is set,
? Current value is within the con?gured upper and lower limits for Mode$06-normalization.
Depending on con?guration of signed Mode$06-values, a conversion of the current-, minimum and maximum
value is done.
The standard value is calculated in analogy to the standard values computation in diagnostics.

5.4.13 ACTION_ARSD_SearchObdsFrfIdx - private function
Description:
This action is looking for the Freeze-frame index corresponding to provided OBDS index.
Formula section:
#Force default return value (= 255)

#Look for Freeze-frame index corresponding to current DFCC and valid
For m = 0 to EWS_noFrz_SC_VW-1

and
(EWS_noDfcFrz_VW [m] = EWS_noDfc_T_VW [PRM_IDX_OBDS]) )
Then
PRM_IDX_FRF = m
Endif
Endfor
return(PRM_IDX_FRF)

� General Information
This module provides the project speci?c con?guration part related to OBD Radar functionality.
The OBD Radar collects input data from aggregates which are linked to a list of diagnostic functions which
need to be monitored.
The data are standardized and provided through one of the following format:
? standard values
? OBDC - mode$06 values.
>A diagnostic function can be monitored by either a standard value data or an OBD mode 06 data or both
data
>A given aggregate might manage several diagnostic functions

� General Information
The OBD radar functionality collects diagnostic standard data values and provides them to customer diagnos-
tic tools for statistics purposes.
These statistics can be used to identify how ?close? the system was to detecting a failure.
The standard values for all functionalities are calculated inside this module.
This module implements the requirements towards OBDR as speci?ed in architecture memorandum 45 "Inter-
faces for OBD Radar functionality" rev01
Index and conditions check con?guration
Refer to chapter 6.3.1 "Index and conditions check con?guration" of memo45.
Using static con?guration, the check of the diagnosis conditions and antibounce counter of the corresponding
failure can be done inside Action_ARSD_SetObds.This is only possible when the related diagnostic is linked to
one failure, otherwise it has to be checked on aggregate side before calling Action_ARSD_SetObds,
Accordingly, the OBDR standard values index shall be linked to a failure index
? if the index is NC_IDX_ERR_NO_ERROR, the check is not performed by the Action_ARSD_SetObds and
shall be done on aggregate side
? if the index corresponds to a failure index, the check is done by Action_ARSD_SetObds, and the aggregate
only needs to take care of additional conditions check

value and the thresholds. In addition, this ACTION checks the diagnosis condition and the anti-bounce
counter if an error index is con?gured for the entry NC_IDX_STD_xxx.
It supports the architecture memo 45 for OBDR standard data production

parameters have the same data resolution and basic type. If the observed data has a basic type not
supported by the ACTION (e.g. u32) then the user shall convert the data to a supported basic type closed to
the original one (e.g. s32).

Okay, here's an analysis of the provided diagram:

## Function

The primary function of this module is to perform statistical data measurements on a configurable number of system variables. This includes:
*   Detection of events when measured variables fall within a defined range.
*   Storing a history of a configurable number of measurements.
*   Applying a low-pass filter to measurements.
*   Triggering these measurements based on two defined trigger conditions.

## Inputs

Based on the diagram, the inputs are primarily from two areas: "Calibrations" and Trigger signals:
*   **Calibrations:**
    *   Measured Variables Definitions (SCxxADR) - Defines the variables being measured.
    *   Class Definitions (SCxxMIS,WIN) - Defines the range (YY Class) for the class event counters.
    *   Trigger Definitions (SCxxTV1, SCxxTV2...) - Defines parameters used for trigger conditions 1 and 2.
    *   Trigger Strategy Definitions (SCxxTP1, TP2...) - Defines additional parameters for the trigger strategy.
    *   Storage Strategy Definitions (SCxxSTP,STM) - Defines the data storage strategy.
* **Triggers:**
    *   TRIG_EVE_1 and TRIG_EVE_2 based on the trigger strategy definitions
*   **Power Latch**: LV_PWL

## Outputs

The main outputs appear to be:
*   **Class Event Counters:**  Counts the occurrences of events based on the calibrated class definitions and measured variables.
*   **History:** A record of past measurements (SMxxHIST[0...9], SMxxPTR).
*   **Low Pass Filter:** Filtered measurements (SMxxLPV).
*   **Saved Event Data:** SAVE_EVE

## Logic Flow

1.  **Calibration Data:**  The module starts with calibration data, including definitions for measured variables, class ranges, and trigger conditions.
2.  **Measurement & Event Detection:** Measured variables (defined by SCxxADR) are monitored.  If a measured variable falls within a defined class/range (SCxxMIS,WIN, SCxxADR), the "Class Event Counters" are incremented.
3.  **Trigger Strategy Evaluation:**  Two trigger strategies (TRIG_EVE) are defined based on SCxxTV1, SCxxTV2, SCxxTP1, and TP2. These strategies likely implement specific conditions to initiate measurement storage.
4.  **Storage Strategy Activation:** When a trigger condition is met, the "Storage Strategy" (SAVE_EVE) is activated based on SCxxSTP, STM parameters. The `TRIG_EVENT LV_PWL` also contributes to storage strategies.
5.  **Data Storage:**  Triggered measurements are stored in the "History" block.
6.  **Filtering:** Measurements are passed through a "Low Pass Filter" to reduce noise.
7.  **Event Saving:**  The trigger events are saved.

The "SAVE_EVE" module receives inputs from "Class Event Counters", "History", and "Low Pass Filter", so this information is stored. The "Power Latch" LV_PWL block seems to gate the storage. The flow shows how the measurement and storage happens.

The Simulink diagram describes a triggering mechanism for data storage. It utilizes two separate trigger paths, each comparing an input variable against a masked and defined threshold value. If the comparison is true, a delayed trigger event is generated to initiate data storage inhibition.

## Inputs

The Simulink diagram has the following main inputs:

*   **SCxxTV1:** Trigger 1 variable definition

*   **TRIG_EVE_2:** Trigger event 2

**Overall Function:**

The diagram shows two independent triggering paths. Each path monitors a different variable and compares it against a specified threshold. If the threshold is met in either path, a corresponding delayed trigger event is generated. This ensures that data is stored at desired instances, separated by a time interval.

## Function

The primary function of this module is to compute storage conditions for a single variable related to data recording in a vehicle. This involves evaluating several signals, including a filtered trigger signal, the beginning of a powerlatch phase, and the end of a powerlatch phase, to determine when data should be saved.

## Inputs

Based on the signal flow diagram and code snippet, the key inputs are:

*   `TRIG_EVE`: The raw trigger signal.
*   `FIL_TRIG_EVE`: The filtered trigger signal.
*   `SCxxSTM`: Save time interval parameters (presumably an array indexed by `xx`).
*   `SCxxSTP`: Save type parameters (presumably an array indexed by `xx`).
*   `LV_PWL`: Power latch signal.
*   `C_SC_STM[xx]`: Calibration parameter related to save time interval
*   `C_SC_STP[xx]`: Calibration parameter related to save type.
*   `NC_NR_DREC_MES_VALUE`: Defines array loop bound index.

## Outputs

*   `SAVE_EVE`: Storage strategy signal/variable (presumably an array indexed by `xx`). This indicates whether a particular condition for saving data is met.

## Logic Flow

The logic flow is implemented within a `for` loop that iterates `xx` from `0` to `NC_NR_DREC_MES_VALUE-1`. Here's a step-by-step breakdown:

1.  **Initialization:**  At reset, all elements of the `SAVE_EVE[xx]` array are initialized to 0.

2.  **Recurrence:** The main logic executes every 100ms.

3.  **Loop Iteration:**  The `for` loop processes each element `xx` of the `SAVE_EVE` array.

4.  **Resetting SAVE_EVE:** If `SAVE_EVE[xx]` is currently 1, it's immediately set to 0. This is likely a mechanism to ensure that a save event isn't triggered repeatedly if conditions remain active.

5.  **Trigger Condition Check:**
    *   It checks if defined calibrated conditions related to trigger are true.

4.  **Resetting SAVE_EVE:** If `SAVE_EVE[xx]` is currently 1, it's immediately set to 0. This is likely a mechanism to ensure that a save event isn't triggered repeatedly if conditions remain active.

5.  **Trigger Condition Check:**
    *   It checks if defined calibrated conditions related to trigger are true.
    *   Inside it, it checks if either of the following conditions is met:
        *   `C_SC_STM[xx] > 0 AND TRIG_EVE[xx] == C_SC_STM[xx] + 1`
        *   `C_SC_STM[xx] == 0 AND TRIG_EVE[xx] == 2`
    *   If either of these conditions is met AND bit0 of `C_SC_STP[xx]` is 1, then `SAVE_EVE[xx]` is set to 1.

6.  **Power Latch Condition Check:**
    *   It checks if defined calibrated conditions related to beginning powerlatch are true.
    *   If the power latch signal `LV_PWL` transitions from 0 to 1 AND bit1 of `C_SC_STP[xx]` is 1, then `SAVE_EVE[xx]` is set to 1.

7.  **Loop Completion:** The `for` loop continues until all elements of the `SAVE_EVE` array have been processed.

In summary, the code appears to be implementing a logic that triggers data saving based on specific combinations of the filtered trigger signal, save time interval, save type, and power latch signal, as well as some calibration parameters. The calibrated parameters and bit selection allow for different trigger conditions to be enabled or disabled.

## Function

The Simulink diagram and accompanying pseudocode/formula describe a data recorder system (ARSD) that analyzes a variable and classifies it into different classes. It then increments a counter associated with that class. The system aims to measure a variable (SCxxADR, SCxxTP) and categorize it based on configured measurement intervals (SCXXBM, MIS, MIW). The class detection logic determines the class index (IDX_CLAS), and the class counter is incremented accordingly.

## Inputs

*   **Variable to Measure:** SCxxADR (Address), SCxxTP (Type) - These define the measured variable itself, including its address and data type.

## Function

The diagram describes a data recorder system (ARSD) history management functionality. Its primary function is to store measured variables (SCxxADR) along with a bitmask (SC_BM) into a history buffer (SM_HIST) on the rising edge of a trigger event (SAVE_EVE). It manages a circular buffer for each channel and keeps track of the oldest data using pointers (SM_PTR).

## Inputs

*   **SCxxADR:** Address of the variable to measure. Represents the one measured variable.
*   **SCxxTP:** Size/type information for the variable to measure.
*   **SC_BM[xx]:** Bitmask to be applied on SC_ADR[xx] value.
*   **SAVE_EVE[xx]:** Trigger event. A transition from 0 to 1 triggers the recording of the variable.
*   **NC_NR_DREC_HIS_CHANNELS:** Represents the maximum number of channels to be recorded in history.

## Outputs

*   **SM_HIST[xx][yy]:** History buffer where the measured variables and their bitmasks are stored. This is an array where `xx` is the channel index, and `yy` is the index in the history buffer for that channel.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:**
    *   When saved memory is lost (presumably after a reset), for each channel `xx` from 0 to `NC_NR_DREC_HIS_CHANNELS-1`, the history pointer `SM_PTR[xx]` is initialized to 0.
    *   For each history index `hh` from 0 to `NC_NR_DREC_HIS_PER_CHANNEL-1`, the history buffer `SM_HIST[xx][hh]` is initialized to 0 for each channel `xx`.

2.  **Activation/Recurrence (every 100ms):**
    *   For each channel `xx` from 0 to `NC_NR_DREC_HIS_CHANNELS-1`, upon a transition from 0 to 1 of the trigger event `SAVE_EVE[xx]`, the history management logic is executed.

3.  **History Management:**
    *   The current value of the measured variable `SC_ADR[xx]` (after appropriate typecasting based on `SC_TP[xx]`) and the bitmask `SC_BM[xx]` are stored in the history buffer at the location pointed to by `SM_PTR[xx]` i.e., `SM_HIST[xx][SM_PTR[xx]] = (SC_ADR[xx]) and C_SC_BM[xx]`.
    *   The history pointer `SM_PTR[xx]` is incremented to point to the next location in the history buffer.
    *   **Circular Buffer Management:** An `if` statement checks if the `SM_PTR[xx]` has reached the end of the history buffer (`NC_NR_DREC_HIS_CHANNELS-1`).
        *   If `SM_PTR[xx]` is less than `NC_NR_DREC_HIS_CHANNELS-1`, it increments the pointer `SM_PTR[xx] = SM_PTR[xx] + 1`.
        *   Otherwise, if `SM_PTR[xx]` has reached the end of the buffer, it is reset to 0, effectively creating a circular buffer, `SM_PTR[xx] = 0`.

This system stores historical data of multiple channels in circular buffers, allowing for analysis of previous states of the measured variables.

## Function

The diagram shows the overall system architecture for OBD (On-Board Diagnostics) Radar functionality, specifically focusing on the computation of standard values used for diagnostic monitoring. The system processes diagnostic information to generate standardized values (between 0 and 1), creates Mode$06 value arrays, calculates standard and maximal values, stores freeze frames, builds histograms, and communicates with a customer tester tool. The system initializes specific arrays related to radar data at system reset.

## Inputs

*   **Diagnostic function 1, 2, ... n:** Diagnostic signals or parameters from various parts of the engine or vehicle system.
*   **Standard values:** Values from relevant diagnostic features or calculated in a central function of existing Mode$06 values.
*   **Mode$06-values:**  Diagnostic data related to Mode$06 OBD parameters.
*   **RST system event:** A reset event triggering initialization of specific arrays.

## Outputs

*   **Standard values:** Standardized values (0 or 1) based on the input from diagnostic functions.
*   **Histograms:** Statistical representation of the standard value profile over time.
*   **Freeze Frames:**  Snapshot of environmental data captured upon specific conditions.
*   **Data to customer tester tool:** All collected and computed data transmitted to the tester for diagnostic analysis.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Diagnostic Input:**  The system receives inputs from various diagnostic functions (e.g., "Diagnostic function 1", "Diagnostic function 2", ..., "Diagnostic function n"). These inputs are either 'Standard Values' or 'Mode$06-values'.

2.  **Mode$06-values Array Creation:** Mode$06 values are used to create arrays.

3.  **Central Function Processing:** The "Central function" block performs several operations:
    *   **Standard values calculation:** Calculates standard values based on the inputs from diagnostic functions and Mode$06 values.
    *   **Maximal values calculation:**  Determines the maximum standard values over a driving cycle or engine lifecycle.
    *   **Freeze-Frames:**  Stores environmental data freeze frames upon the occurrence of certain diagnostic conditions.

4.  **Statistics Function Processing:** The "Statistics function" block performs:
    *   **Histogram calculation:** Creates a histogram of the standard values, providing a statistical profile of the diagnostic data.
    *   **Tester connection function:** Handles the communication with a customer tester tool.

5.  **Data Output:** The processed data, including standard values, maximal values, freeze frames, and histograms, is sent to the customer tester tool via the "Basis SW for tester communication" block, enabling diagnostic analysis and troubleshooting.

6. **Array Initialization:** At the beginning, during a system Reset (RST) several arrays related to radar data are initialized using a for loop, setting specific parameters like EWS_r_VW, EWS_stRate_VW, and EWS_posnName_VW to initial values.
